reviewText: A great video of a great writer of our century.
I'd already seen it on American Masters on PBS. I ordered it because I liked it.

As a long-time devotee of August Wilson's work, I agree with many other critics and theater historians (like me) that place Wilson in the ranks of O'Neill, Albee, Miller, Williams and Foote...one of our greats whose work will endure and enrich the American theater forever.  This is a superb documentary on Wilson's life and work.  If you teach high school or university students, this is a fine introduction.  I am depressed that only ONE film of a Wilson play has been made: "The Piano Lesson."  We should all beg Oprah Winfrey's production company to correct this injustice!

Timely recognition of accomplished play writer and fascinating telling of the Hill District in Pittsburgh. Overview of his creativity, poetry and theatrical genius are discussed by his colleagues and actors. I must have for any student of American theater.
This unknown history should be shared with all black youths and adults, to discover all great people of color who are left out of black history month.
This is wonderful...I've seen several of his plays and it's nice to understand the man behind them.
We are celebrating Black History Month in our film group which meets every Saturday and this film, appropriately leads off the month long celebration!
very interesting. Too bad than only a couple of the plys have been filmed in theater
A beautiful story of an artist who cared deeply not only about his art, but also his community.
Indeed, a very informative representation of August Wilson's great contribution to American theatre.
Truely a gifted writer. August Wilson was a true American. I loved every minute of this documentary and shared it with friends and family.
